Patch Set 22:

(1 comment)
This change needs some tests
Similar to the write counterpart, I prefer we name this `decode_oem_meta_file_io_read_req()`
Done
Please remove the `wip: ` prefix if this is no-longer a work-in-progress change.
Done. Please check, thank you.
Please say something more descriptive here. Can you provide some context for the message and maybe document the serialised message layout (that way we can make sure it matches the implementation).
Done. Please check, thank you.
Done
Hi Lora, I've outlined a number of concerns inline.
Please name this `pldm_oem_meta_fileio_read_option`

Done. Change to pldm_oem_meta_file_io_read_option.
Please check, thank you.
Similar to the review comment above: `pldm_oem_meta_fileio_read_req`, and fix the doxygen to be consistent.

Done. Change to pldm_oem_meta_file_io_read_req.
Please check, thank you.

This is not a valid flexible array definition. Please see the guidance here:

https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/docs/checklists/changes.md?plain=1#L89-L102

Done. Use pointers instead of flexible arrays.
Please check, thank you.
`pldm_oem_meta_fileio_read_data_info`, and fix the doxygen.

Done. Change to pldm_oem_meta_file_io_read_data_info.
Please check, thank you.
`file_io` or `fileio`? Can we please be consistent.

Done. All modified parts are changed to file_io.
Please check, thank you.
If `struct pldm_oem_meta_read_file_req` contains a flexible array member then you must also pass the length of the `req` object through the API.

Done. Added req_length parameter to check whether the total length of the requested message meets expectations.
Please check, thank you.

You use `req->length` in the call immediately below, but you've neither checked the return value of `pldm_msgbuf_extract()` here, nor verified that the decoded length is in any way sensible. `msgbuf` will prevent out-of-bounds reads, but let's avoid even attempting them if we can determine the value isn't sensible to begin with. For instance `req->length < payload_length` seems like a sensible check.

Done. Checks whether the total length of the request message is the same as the provided length plus the minimum decoded length.
Please check, thank you.
Modify according to suggestions. Please help to review. Thank you.
A bit of a nit-pick, but I would prefer we drop the bullet points, they don't contribute much to the communication.
I've removed the bullet points description. Please check, thank you.
Hi Lora, I have a few comments inline.
This also needs some tests added.
`FILEIO` here is inconsistent with using an underscore between `file` and `io` in the type names. Please use `FILE_IO` here, or no underscore everywhere else.
Change to FILE_IO. Please check, thank you.
Also here.
Change to FILE_IO. Please check, thank you.
If we have a pair of parameters that represent an object and its length, please be consistent and put the length parameter after the object pointer. In this case, order `req_length` after `req`.
Done. Please check, thank you.
I don't understand why a read request would be providing data. Wouldn't this be the case for the response?

read_info needs to include the information of the reading file.
Take reading file data as an example: read_info needs to contain length (read file length), transferFlag, highOffset and lowOffset to know the starting position, length and transfer progress of the read file.
I'm sorry, but your explanation is not making sense to me. Why are we dealing with an opaque array?

If we want to extract the information of the read file io command, we need dealing with the array here.
Please tell me how I can resolve your concerns, thank you.

That would make sense if you were decoding the read _response_, but this function is decoding the read _request_. There can't be data, the message is requesting that a read be performed.

Please add a document in `docs/oem/meta/` that describes the serialised layout of each of the messages (requests and responses) that you're adding in this series. This should be in the same manner as done in the DMTF documents: A table containing type and description columns, with rows documenting the order of the fields in the message. This needs to be written down and considered in its own right, so that we have a reference for the _implementation_ of the serialisation functions (encode/decode).

Thank you for your reply.
I will add a file_io_function_description.md under the docs/oem/meta/ path to explain the use of the read file io command, thank you.

I have added file_io_function_description.md to explain the use of the read file io command.
Please help to review, thank you.
Hi Lora, along with resolving the discussions in-line, this change still needs test cases added.
I have revised it. Please help to review. Thank you.
Perhaps `-EOVERFLOW`?
Done. Please check, thank you.
See the discussion on PS 12.
Modifications have been made according to the suggestions. Please review. Thank you.

This isn't readable and doesn't render as a table:

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/plugins/gitiles/openbmc/libpldm/+/refs/changes/58/72758/19/docs/oem/meta/file_io_function_description.md

Please fix the markdown:

https://github.github.com/gfm/#tables-extension-
It has been modified according to the suggestions, but the table displayed by markdown does not seem to be as expected ?
I think these enum members should be assigned explicit values.
Done. Please check. Thank you.
This should be a flexible array like we have on line 36 above (along with the helper function for accessing the data in C++).
Done. Please check. Thank you.
Please see how the checks are done in `decode_oem_meta_file_io_write_req()` above and do the same here.
Done. Please check. Thank you.
Hi Lora, I've provided an explicit example of the markdown table syntax example I was after. The documentation isn't readable as it stands and this needs to be fixed.

You've replaced it with HTML content - that's not what the documentation I linked to on PS19 was suggesting at all. The HTML in the GFM documentation is demonstrating the _rendered output_ from the markdown syntax. 

The example syntax is:

```
| foo | bar |
| --- | --- |
| baz | bim |
```

Which renders like:

| foo | bar |
| --- | --- |
| baz | bim |

That's all I'm asking for here.

Thank you for your explanation.
I have modified it as suggested. Please check, thank you.

According to the link check, it seems that the table can be displayed normally.
link：https://gerrit.openbmc.org/plugins/gitiles/openbmc/libpldm/+/refs/changes/58/72758/22/docs/oem/meta/file_io_function_description.md
